conclusion: Understanding the processes involved in the p-V diagram.
The p-V diagram shows two adiabatic processes and two isochoric processes.
Adiabatic processes involve no heat exchange, and internal energy changes are due to work done.
Isochoric processes occur at constant volume, with internal energy change due to heat exchange.
For an ideal gas, internal energy is a function of temperature only, U ∝ T.
Adiabatic process described by pV^γ = constant; temperature increases with compression and decreases with expansion.
In an isochoric process, change in internal energy is directly proportional to temperature change.
Identify states and processes on the diagram, such as state a connected to state c.
To compare internal energies at states a and c, determine the temperature change.
If state c is reached from state a via an adiabatic process, calculate temperature at state c using adiabatic relation.
If state c is reached via an isochoric process, temperature change is related to heat exchange.
Internal energy at state c will be higher or lower than at state a depending on the process and temperature change.
